Living beings

Before to proceed, please, think a little bit:

Reflection 1: About the life
How do you define living beings?

The actual definition is done, grouping characteristics that only living beings can have. Some characteristics are listed in Khan Academy and by Pedro Loos (Khan Academy, "What is life?" ; Loos, Pedro, 2022):

  • Organization: They are made of one or more cells, that have specialized parts in some vital function.
  • Metabolism: Chemical reactions that allow living beings to obtain energy.
  • Homeostasis: The capacity to regulate their vital functions.
  • Growth: The capacity to keep the morphology functional.
  • Reproduction: Living beings can perpetuate their specie.
  • Response: Living beings have answers to external stimulation or changes in the environment, and also to internal changes.
  • Evolution: The living beings, every time they make another living beings, they can change, and transmit the new adaptive characteristics to their descendants (Pirula, 2013 ; Iamarino, Atila, 2023).

, and as they highlight, this is a general list, that it is not unique, we could also add nutrition, the capacity to obtain from organic or/and inorganic primary sources elements capable to sustain other vital functions.

The understanding of living beings, however, it was not always the same. Among the Mesoamerican indigenous, it is possible to observe a giant respect with other natural elements, like the rocks, that were capable to have "communication" (Popol Vuh, 2021, pp. 38 ; Popol Vuh, 1954, Ch. 3, pp. 7), but the rocks did not happen relevance only in Mesoamerica. Juan Antonio Garcia Castro expose beliefs of different cultures linked to "Piedras de Rayo" [lightning stone], remembering the importance of rocks in our development (Garcia Castro, Juan Antonio, 1988).

The fact that ancient people considered rocks capable to have the same living beings characteristics can be a surprise for some people, or even to let people uncomfortable. This is a discussion far from the end. Lucia Santaella shows that in 19th century, Charles. S. Pierce attributed the capability to think to other living beings, and he also expanded the thinking to crystals (Santaella, Lucia, 2020).

Organization, Reproduction and Evolution

Despite the living beings characteristics do not be a well-defined list, three of them are fundamental in this step of our study, so we need to study them deeper.

The living beings have at least a cell (Collection Cell Biology, National Geographic), that has an organization allowing them to reproduce and having evolution, but which part of the living beings is responsible for these steps of the life? The answer to this question was not discovered with a unique paper. Firstly, Charles Darwin described the origin of species, the evolution, through observations (Evolution: Changing Species Over Time, National Geographic). A few years later, Gregor Mendel proposed the existence of a model where traits are inherited according to a rule of dominant and recessive combination, during the reproduction (Miko, Ilona, 2008). The two theories are the basis for our understanding about how species, like us, appear on earth. But, we were still missing where inside the organisms these changes happened. The final piece of the puzzle was added by Friedrich Miescher that named it "nuclein", but it was renamed later for "deoxyribonucleic acid", the famous DNA (Pray, Leslie A., 2008). Therefore, it is necessary to say that when DNA was discovered, it was not discovered its functionality. The DNA definition and how its structure has relationship with hereditary information came only during 20th century (Alberts B, Johnson A, Lewis J, et al., 2002). It is thanks to the DNA that our organism has its organization.

Chromosome, DNA and RNA

The inheritance in the living beings are made by genetic material, the chromatin (Cooper GM., 2000), that is condensed to chromosomes during cell division. We can group the living beings and virus, that are not considered living beings for everybody (Khan Academy, "What is life?"), according to their genetic material's structure and localization (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, 2024):
  • Virus have their chromosome made either by DNA or RNA.
  • The living beings that do not have chromosomes inside a nucleus (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, 2023 ; Martin, William F., et al., 2015, pp. 3 - 5) in their cells, they have chromosome exclusively made by DNA.
  • The living beings that have chromosome inside nucleus (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, 2023 ; Martin, William F., et al., 2015, pp. 3 - 5) in cells, they have DNA linked with proteins.

Like the planets, the life organization may also grow in structures, from the simplest to the most complex. The RNA has a simple strand of nucleoids, while the DNA has two in twisted helix format (Minchin S, Lodge J., 2019). Despite to be simpler than DNA, it is not possible to consider that RNA was the first molecule to store inheritance information and catalysis (Alberts B, Johnson A, Lewis J, et al., 2002).

Mitochondrial DNA

Beside DNA in our cells, living beings that have mitochondria also have another DNA known as mitochondrial DNA, mtDNA (Ladoukakis, Emmanuel D., and Eleftherios Zouros., 2017). We would like to highlight the following aspects on Emmanuel D. Ladoukakise e Zouros Eleftherios' work:
  • The mitochondria, where we can find the mtDNA, it is reminiscent of a joint experience between bacteria that created better live conditions in an endosymbiont process (Martin, William F., et al., 2015, pp. 3 - 5).
  • The mtDNA is shorter than DNA.
  • It is having evolution for more than 2000000000 (2 billion) of years.
  • It has different functions in living beings.
  • The mammals (Wilson, D. E. , Armstrong, . David M. and Jones, . J. Knox, 2023), like us, the mtDNA is transmitted only by mothers, but there are exceptions to this rule among the living beings. We have to highlight the phenomenon named heteroplasmy that allows inheritance of parental mtDNA, but it is an uncommon phenomenon.

Ancestry

The DNA genes define part of organisms that has it, allowing us to trace common ancestors, for example, living beings that have five digits in their limbs (Tabin, Clifford J., 1992), like birds, reptiles, we, among other animals, have a common ancestor (Minchin S, Lodge J., 2019). When Charles Darwin built his theory, without genetic knowledge, it was made through living being's observation (Darwin, Charles, 19--, Vol. I ; Darwin, Charles, 19--, Vol. II).

As living beings have chromosomes, responsible to define their characteristics, it is possible through them to make a scheme that allows to trace possible common ancestors. This scheme is known as a phylogenetic tree (Khan Academy: "Phylogenetic trees" ; Bear, Robert et al., 2020, pp. 51, 52 ). Of course, it is not only among living beings that is possible to make connection, it is also possible to find connections among us. Through analysis of phylogenetic trees (Weissensteiner, Hansi, et al., 2016), using a phylogenetic group named haplogroup (ISOGG Wiki, 2022), we can find our common ancestors.

F is the common ancestor of C and D. The source code is available in GitHub of the project (History Tracers, 2024)

The human DNA is composed with twenty-three chromosome pairs (Minchin S, Lodge J., 2019), twenty-two of these pairs are named autosomes, they do not define the individual sex, the remaining chromosome pair, that defines sex, is known as sexual chromosome (National Human Genome Research Institute, Autossome). This separation of chromosome between autosomes and sexual, it is allowing advances in understanding about the population, as it is shown by Shinichiro Ogawa e Satoh Masahiro (Ogawa, Shinichiro, and Masahiro Satoh, 2022).

The mitochondrial DNA is used to study maternal lineage, because paternal mitochondrial is "discarded" during fecundation (Groleau, Rick, 2002, PBS). During the evolution process, different ways to discard parental mitochondrial DNA were made, in mammals, like us, they are modified and degraded after fecundation (Sato, Miyuki, and Ken Sato, 2013).

When we wish to map patrilineal lineage, it is studied Y chromosome, because only men inherit it (Louw, Marti, 2000, PBS). The idea that Y chromosome was enough to define the male sex was widely spread, but recent researches has shown that other genes present in autosomes and in X chromosome are also responsible to determine sex. This discovery was also for XX chromosome, this fact helped us to discover XX male and XY female (Gilbert SF., 2000 ; Karkanaki, A., et al., 2007).

The chromosome X, acts to define the person sex, but not only this, it has also known that among its functions, it also has relationship with immunological systems (https://doi.org/10.1038/nri2815).

Questions

    Answer the questions:
  1. Is there a unique list of characteristics defining the living beings? .
  2. Do we always had a unique understanding about living beings? .
  3. Do the molecules storing hereditary information, the DNA and RNA, responsible for changes in organisms and the evolution? .
  4. When a living being has mitochondria, does it have more than one DNA? .
